citeinfo.title: Annual Report of the Bering-Aleutian Salmon International Survey (BASIS), 2003

abstract.p: The Bering-Aleutian Salmon International Survey (BASIS) is an NPAFC-coordinated program of ecosystem research on salmon in the Bering Sea. The major goal of this program, which was developed in 2001, is to clarify how changes in ocean conditions affect the survival and growth of salmon. The plan for BASIS research calls for synoptic research vessel operations across the entire Bering Sea in 2002-2006 to collect information on oceanographic conditions, salmon, and associated species. In-depth biological and stock identification analyses will determine ocean growth and life history characteristics of regional salmon stocks. BASIS data will be used in spatially-explicit models, incorporating information on ocean conditions and salmon migration, growth, and mortality processes, to advance our understanding of the causes of changes in productivity of salmon populations. The second BASIS field season was completed in 2003.
This report also provides a list of BASIS publications, reports, and manuscripts.

[Reference: North Pacific Anadromous Fish Commission. 2004. Annual Report of the Bering-Aleutian Salmon International Survey (BASIS), 2003. NPAFC Doc. 769. BASIS Working Group, North Pacific Anadromous Fish Commission, Vancouver, B.C., Canada. 78 p.]

descript.purpose: To document summaries of preliminary results of BASIS field research in 2003, as well as new results from ongoing analyses of 2002-2003 BASIS samples and data.

distinfo.distliab: While every effort has been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable within the limits of the current state of the art, NOAA cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in the data, nor as a result of the failure of the data to function on a particular system.
